text:
Ski resorts in Japan publish updated plans for 2015-16
Niseko – new accommodation opening up. Until the end of October, visitors to Niseko can enjoy decorated cow-spotting as part of ‘cow parade’ – the world’s largest public art event. 47 cows, all lavishly painted by Japanese designers and artists, have been dotted around the Niseko area, with all proceeds from the installations going to non-profit organizations.
Brand new accommodation is opening in Hirafu Village in December 2015. The new building, Kozue, will offer 2 and 3 bedroom apartments with a prime location within easy access of the slopes. Floor to ceiling windows will provide stunning views over Niseko’s extraordinary landscape.
A major new resort area, Irenka Village, will soon be developed in Niseko. This is the biggest and most ambitious land development to come to Niseko so far, and large plots are available for purchase for commercial construction. These developments will take place in Niseko Grand Hirafu. Read more about Irenka Village here.
Furano – more off-piste action!
Towards the end of last season Furano Ski Area implemented a new system for accessing off-piste areas, with four new access points on the resort. Skiers and snowboarders hoping to access these areas must submit a registration form to the ski patrol team beforehand for safety reasons.
A new rental shop has opened in Kitanomine Village. “Alpine Backcountry Rental” specializes in backcountry equipment rental and sales.
Lift pass updates:
Children aged 12 years and under can receive free passes for lifts, which is not dependent upon the presence of a paying adult.
The life pass exchange programme with Kamui Ski Links and Tomamu will continue this season. This exchange allows five-to-seven day Furano Ski Area pass holders to access a one day pass at either Kamui Ski Links or Tomamu, whilst eight-day pass holders are entitled to a one day lift pass at both of these alternate resorts. This exchange voucher can be obtained on the morning of, or day before, customers intend to visit Kamui or Tomamu.
This offer does not apply to child tickets.
Nozawa Onsen – New Year fun and snowfield tours
Nozawa Onsen are offering snowfield sightseeing tours – a rare opportunity to ride on a snow vehicle which will allow out-of-the-ordinary views of the snowscapes. These tours have several daily departures and will cost just 500 yen (£2.70), including a drink.
Nozawa Onsen are also running an exciting ski and snowboarding related event to celebrate the New Year. To welcome the arrival of 2016, late-night ski slopes will be open until 11:30pm, after which there will be huge fireworks displays above the slopes, and free sake or mulled wine for all customers!
Rusutsu – Rusutsu resort goes international
Rusutsu Resort has gone into partnership with Starwood Hotels & Resorts in a re-branding of the Rusutsu Resort Tower Hotel.
From December 2015, the hotel will be renamed the “Westin Rusutsu Resort”. This deal marks the first Starwood Ski Resort in Japan, a collaboration which will enhance Rusutsu’s appeal to international visitors, as well as winter sports fans in Japan.
The new Westin Rusutsu Resort will feature 210 guestrooms, including seven-bed suites for large groups or families. Hakuba – introducing ‘Hakuba Valley All Area Season Pass’
Brand new properties in Hakuba for winter 2015-16 include: Bluebird Chalets, Wadano Woods Chalets, Winterstorm Apartments and Phoenix Cocoon Chalets.
Ski and snowboard fans will be delighted to hear news of the new ‘Hakuba Valley All Area Season Pass’. The pass enables customers to enjoy 144 ski trails and 110 lifts all in one pass.
More off-piste terrain has opened up at Hakuba since last season, and shuttles to the resort area from Haneda airport are now available with Nagano Snow Shuttle.
